channel.title: NYT > Science
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: NASA Shakes Up Artemis Schedule, Aiming for 2 Moon Landings in 2028
item.description: A “back to basics” approach resembles the Apollo program of the 1960s, with more missions launching more often. NASA officials said that it would be safer and faster.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: NASA’s Space Launch System rocket and Orion capsule were rolled into the Vehicle Assembly Building at Kennedy Space Center in Florida on Wednesday.

item.title: What Your DNA Reveals About the Sex Life of Neanderthals
item.description: Most people alive today carry fragments of Neanderthal DNA in their genome. Now scientists are gaining a more intimate understanding of the ancient encounters that put it there.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:description: An artist’s rendering of a human skull, at left, and a Neanderthal skull. Most people alive today carry a bit of Neanderthal DNA in their genome, the result of interbreeding tens of thousands of years ago.

item.title: Bird Flu Strikes California Elephant Seals for the First Time
item.description: Thirty seals, primarily weaned pups, have died since late last week, scientists said.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes and Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Elephant seals at Año Nuevo State Park in Pescadero, Calif., last month.

item.title: The Password That Lets Caterpillars Hide in an Ant’s Lair
item.description: Some butterfly species can’t grow unless they trick ants into taking them home with a complex rhythmic signal.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Dzombak
item.category: Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences

item.title: T. Rex Ran on Its Tiptoes ‘Like an 8-Ton Chicken’
item.description: New findings about the anatomy of the dinosaur age’s fiercest predator suggest it chased prey “like an oversized bird.”
item.dc:creator: Jack Tamisiea
item.media:description: Assembling a Tyrannosaurus rex skeleton for a Christie’s auction in Singapore in 2022.

item.title: Norway’s Century-Long Watch on the Northern Lights
item.description: The nation’s northern region has led the scientific quest to understand the aurora borealis. This summer, a 10,000-antenna radar is expected to begin the next phase of exploration.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil and Michal Siarek
item.media:credit: Michał Siarek for The New York Times

item.title: How a Horse Whinnies: With a Whistle and a Song
item.description: Horses, with their high-pitched whinnies, seemed to buck the trend of larger animals producing lower sounds, but a new study explains the mechanics behind the noises a horse makes.
item.dc:creator: Kate Golembiewski

item.title: The Evolution of Eyes Began With One
item.description: Even Charles Darwin was puzzled by the evolution of the vertebrate eye. New research suggests that it traces back to a cyclopean invertebrate with a single eye atop the head.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:description: Scientists believe invertebrates 560 million years ago had a single eye at the top of their head, which only later split in two.

item.title: Cities May Be ‘Evolutionary Training Grounds’ For Spotted Lanternflies
item.description: Living in urban China may have given the insects the traits they needed to thrive in the United States, a new study suggests.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Spotted lanternflies, native to Shanghai, have spread rapidly throughout the Eastern United States since they were first discovered there in 2014, invading about 20 states and counting.

item.title: Can Nations Agree How to Mine the Sea? This Is the Year, She Says.
item.description: Leticia Carvalho heads a global authority that’s been struggling to set rules for a decade. President Trump’s aggressive push on ocean mining makes her task more urgent.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.media:credit: Natalie Keyssar for The New York Times

item.title: Caesar Rodney statue to get place of honor in Washington
item.description: Caesar Rodney, whose statue was placed in storage amid racial injustice protests in 2020, will be honored in Washington this summer.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: A bronze statue of Caesar Rodney, a Declaration of Independence signer, on a galloping horse stood in downtown Wilmington, Del., for nearly 100 years until it was removed in 2020.

item.title: Judge Approves $345 Million Verdict Against Greenpeace in Dakota Access Pipeline Suit
item.description: Greenpeace has said the verdict could bankrupt it. The lawsuit was over the group’s role in protests against the Dakota Access Pipeline.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:description: Protesters against the Dakota Access Pipeline in North Dakota in 2016.

item.title: Fighting Wildfires Could Soon Get Harder
item.description: Simultaneous emergencies in different parts of the world could stop countries from sharing ground crews and equipment, new research warns.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Dzombak
item.media:description: A wildfire this month in Chubut Province, Argentina. Different parts of the world have historically had different fire seasons, allowing regions to rotate resources.

item.title: Edward L. Deci, 83, Dies; Found Self-Determination as a Key to Happiness
item.description: His work with his colleague Richard Ryan changed how psychologists understand human motivation and what people require to flourish.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: Vanguard Settles Case Claiming It Tried to Kill the Coal Industry
item.description: Republican-led states had accused financial firms of colluding against coal producers. Vanguard also agreed not to push for action to fight climate change.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:description: Ken Paxton, the Texas attorney general who filed the suit in 2024.

item.title: C.D.C.’s New Acting Director Draws Unexpected Praise From Agency Staff
item.description: Dr. Jay Bhattacharya, who was appointed to the role last week, has offered to publicly endorse vaccination, in particular the measles vaccine, winning over some agency employees.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Dr. Jay Bhattacharya, the director of the National Institutes of Health, is also serving as the acting director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

item.title: Bird Losses Are Accelerating, New Study Finds
item.description: Scientists studying data collected over more than three decades found accelerating losses. Their research offers clues about the causes.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.media:description: The steepest losses in the study, from 1987 to 2021, were seen in Florida, Texas, Louisiana and Arizona.

item.title: Space X Wants to Launch 1 Million Satellites, but Is There Room?
item.description: Elon Musk wants to launch a million satellites, but researchers say global warming is changing the upper atmosphere in ways that makes space junk linger.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.media:description: An Ariane 5 rocket launched from French Guiana last year. Its two satellites joined the roughly 13,000 already in orbit.

item.title: New A.C.A. Plans Could Increase Family Deductibles to $31,000
item.description: The Trump administration is proposing Obamacare plans that it says will lower health insurance premiums. But critics warn they would make care unaffordable.
item.dc:creator: Reed Abelson
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
item.media:description: Dr. Mehmet Oz, who oversees Medicare and Medicaid, promoted new proposals that he said would lower costs. Critics fear the options will increase medical bills and drive people out of insurance plans.

item.title: Trump Says Tech Firms Should Pay More for Electricity
item.description: The president said he had negotiated a deal with tech giants to cover the energy costs of data centers, but offered few details. Experts said such pledges could prove difficult in practice.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Microsoft data center under construction in Goodyear, Ariz., last month.

item.title: Trump’s Pick to Manage Public Lands Pledges No Mass Sell-Off
item.description: Steve Pearce, President Trump’s nominee to lead the Bureau of Land Management, has a long history of pushing to privatize federal property.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: Steve Pearce, the nominee for the Bureau of Land Management, during a news conference in 2023 in Albuquerque, N.M., when he was the chair of the state’s Republican Party.

item.title: Leader of Columbia Brain Institute Quits Over Friendship With Epstein
item.description: The Nobel laureate Richard Axel is not accused of wrongdoing but called his association with Jeffrey Epstein a “serious error in judgment.”
item.dc:creator: Sharon Otterman
item.media:description: Dr. Richard Axel was a co-director of the Mortimer B. Zuckerman Mind Brain Behavior Institute at Columbia University,

item.title: Susan Leeman, 95, Dies; Explored How the Brain Influences the Body
item.description: In an era of overt sexism in the sciences, she made two major discoveries, including identifying a chemical signal in the brain linked to chronic pain and migraines.
item.dc:creator: Delthia Ricks

item.title: Plastic, Plastic Everywhere
item.description: We talk to the author of a new book about why the problem is so hard to solve.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.category: Plastic Inc.: The Secret History and Shocking Future of Big Oil's Biggest Bet (Book)
item.media:description: “If you go to the supermarket and you buy a bunch of bananas and they come wrapped in plastic, you did not demand plastic wrapping,” the author Beth Gardiner said.

item.title: Judge Axes Exxon’s Defamation Suit Against Environmentalists
item.description: But the case against the California attorney general, prompted by his lawsuit over Exxon’s plastic recycling program, can proceed in Texas federal court.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:description: The Exxon Mobil Baytown refinery in Texas last month.

item.title: 15 States Sue the Trump Administration Over Vaccine Schedule Revisions
item.description: Federal health officials have pared back the number of shots recommended for children. The states, led by Democrats, say the changes were not based on science.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The lawsuit seeks to reverse the Trump administration’s decision in January to reduce the number of diseases children are routinely vaccinated against to 11 from 17.

item.title: Leah Stavenhagen, Advocate for Young Women With A.L.S., Dies at 33
item.description: She started a group intended to counter the notion that A.L.S. was an “older white man’s disease.”
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Lucy Lu for The New York Times
item.media:description: Leah Stavenhagen, right, with her mother, Susan Stavenhagen, at a retreat in North Falmouth, Mass., last August.

item.title: Another C.D.C. Vaccine Skeptic Steps Down
item.description: Dr. Ralph Abraham, the agency’s principal deputy director, has called the Covid vaccines “dangerous.” Other skeptics have recently left federal health roles.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Hilary Scheinuk/The Advocate, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Dr. Ralph Abraham resigned less than three months into the job.

item.title: Supreme Court to Weigh Oil-Industry Effort to End a Major Climate Suit
item.description: The case could have significant bearing on a range of other lawsuits brought against the fossil fuel industry by cities and states across the country.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Rachel Ellis/The Denver Post, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A Suncor Energy oil refinery in Commerce City, Colo.
